body:
While working on these changes I developed a new test case:

- 6 Partitions
- 200/400/600/800/1000/2000 messages per partition
- Test Samza job logs every 100 messages per partition.  Does nothing else.
- Always starts at the beginning of the topic.
- Calculated run time as difference time between the last "100th message processed" log and the "Entering run loop." log.

I tested:

- master code as it was earlier this week.
- Version of code with separate delay/block methods.
- Latest version with one delay/block method.

I tested 4 variations of the parameters and ran each scenario 3 times.  Again these are on my dev box so the background load is not well controlled.  There will be some variations run to run.

Here are the results (which look good to me):

¬† | ¬† | ¬† | Got Thread | Got Single | Process | Run Loop | ¬† | ¬† | Current Code | ¬† | ¬† | First Fix: a7c0ac4 | ¬† | ¬† | Current Fix: ef0e53b | ¬†
-- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | --
pool.size | thread.mode | ¬† | Pool Size | Thread Mode | Thread | Mode | ¬† | Run 1 | Run 2 | Run 3 | Run 1 | Run 2 | Run 3 | Run 1 | Run 2 | Run 3
not specified | true | ¬† | 0 | true | ThreadJob | single thread | ¬† | 126 | 126 | 113 | 103 | 98 | 95 | 110 | 130 | 102
not specified | not specified | ¬† | 0 | false | ThreadJob | asynchronous | ¬† | 156 | 141 | 149 | 116 | 137 | 135 | 111 | 135 | 105
1 | not specified | ¬† | 1 | false | Container Thread | asynchronous | ¬† | 17,560 | 17,642 | 18,272 | 179 | 165 | 211 | 182 | 180 | 216
6 | not specified | ¬† | 6 | false | Container Thread | asynchronous | ¬† | 17,097 | 16,921 | 17,526 | 229 | 210 | 162 | 215 | 184 | 167
¬†

Just FYI, this is how long it takes to get from "Entering run loop." log to the last "200th message processed" log (all 6 partitions have at least 200 messages).  Up to tis point the current code generally runs about as fast as the new code.  It supports the conclusion that the problem only occurs once the partitions have started to exhaust.

@lhaiesp Any system that provides callbacks as well as flush (e.g. kinesis and kafka) should extend AsyncSystemProducer. Event hubs is the one of the few systems that doesn't provide flush semantics.
@prateekm This has been implemented already. Closing the pull request now. Thanks for the reminder!

Thanks a lot for this Bharat, 

In regards to the pending task points above mentioned, here is my update:
3. This can be avoided by just spinning up a producer and producing to input stream, I will have a prototype for low level (Async and Sync) out soon, you can refer to that 
4. This too can be avoided since spinning up a producer in start initializes the stream, I have a working prototype for it. The idea of serializing it and again reading from config is redundant

One more thing to be considered in the system is the support of bounded streams, i.e we need to put an EndOfStreamMessage in a stream partition, this can only be done in consumer poll() as of current design.

Thanks

Had an offline discussion with @srinipunuru on this:
1. I incorrectly assumed the map-function instantiation impacts throughput. Turns out this is a non-issue.
2. @srinipunuru will submit a follow-up PR to this that addresses the following:
  i) We will remove the ConfigBasedGrouperFactory in favor of Samza's GroupBySSP + SSPMatcher interfaces
 ii) Currently, the test supports only a single task instance and assigns all partitions to it, We agreed that supporting multiple tasks (with each processing their own partitions) is a more representative throughput test.

@prateekm @bharathkk 
IMHO, JobModel is meant to store the task to partitions assignment and logically config does not belong there. 
We have used it so far to propagate config to SamzaContainer running on a NodeManager in yarn.
I think in long term, we should move it out of the JobModel.

For now, I will add a comment for it.

Working on benchmarking

1. The current implementation use a single client with one thread per-partition. It'd be really interesting if having a client-instance per-partition performs better. 
2. Currently the shut-down of the container is dependent on the time it takes for ehClient.close() - since it's on the shutdown path. Should also ensure that adding multiple clients does not increase the shut-down timeout.

Summarizing offline discussion with @vjagadish1989, @jmakes and @cameronlee314:

While this PR looks pretty good and will work as-is, it would be cleaner to take a different approach to the API.

The suggestion is to deprecate the current `ExtendedSystemAdmin#getNewestOffset(SystemStreamPartition ssp, Integer maxRetries)` API and add a new `SystemAdmin#getSystemStreamMetadata(Set<SystemStreamPartition> ssps)` API instead. This new API is an optimization of the existing `SystemAdmin#getSystemStreamMetadata(Set<String> streams)` API, in that it allows fetching metadata for specific partitions instead of the entire stream. The default implementation of this new API can fetch metadata for all streams in the requested SSP set using the current API, and select the SSPs that were requested. Systems can override this if a better batch API is available.

Then, we can add a cache on top of this new API that has similar prefetch logic as in this PR. For example, it could be a use-case specific `ChangelogMetadataCache` that maintains metadata for the changelog partitions for the container, and is used by the TaskStorageManager. Alternatively, it could be a more general implementation of the StreamMetadataCache, (or a separate SSPMetadataCache) that maintains metadata for all SSPs used in the container. We could also tune the cache TTL based on the commit interval such that we reduce the frequency of metadata fetches.

@xinyuiscool Could you, please, review this change when you get a chance?
@xinyuiscool : Can you please provide a bit more background on why we need the new API for BEAM? Instead, could the iterator be lazy-loaded where it is used?

@vjagadish : sure. BEAM needs an Iterable interface so that it can create iterators when it's needed (can happen multiple times too). The iterator needs to be set to be the starting position from the snapshot when the iterable was created. So for rocksDb, I reset the position when returning the iterator (no concurrency within a task allowed here), and for inmemory, I creates a submap so I can create new iterator for it every time.
Thank you for taking the time to review the PR, Boris. I have responded to your comments. Please, give it another look when you get a chance.

Seems from the rocksDb doc, snapshot is way more expensive than iterator:

A Snapshot API allows an application to create a point-in-time view of a database. The Get and Iterator APIs can be used to read data from a specified snapshot. In a sense, a Snapshot and an Iterator both provide a point-in-time view of the database, but their implementations are different. Short-lived/foreground scans are best done via an iterator while long-running/background scans are better done via a snapshot. An iterator keeps a reference count on all underlying files that correspond to that point-in-time-view of the database - these files are not deleted until the Iterator is released. A snapshot, on the other hand, does not prevent file deletions; instead the compaction process understands the existence of snapshots and promises never to delete a key that is visible in any existing snapshot.

Snapshots are not persisted across database restarts: a reload of the RocksDB library (via a server restart) releases all pre-existing snapshots.

2. Why do we need it?

4. What is the current behavior?
5. What users need to do as part of opting in?

Hopefully, that captures most of what we want to convey to the users.
merged, and submitted.. thank you!

Discussed with @shanthoosh offline. Currently, the synchronization model of this class is convoluted to understand. We currently maintain state in a combination of volatile variables, some non-volatile variables and atomic-references being set/reset.  We should consider simplifying and updating it via a single lock for all the state changes. This will ensure that there's a clear ordering among updates and will also achieve atomicity when updating state-variables.

To close the loop on this PR. Had an offline discussion with @xinyuiscool, @nickpan47 and @prateekm and we agreed on the following:
- The need for the BEAM runner is to return an `Iterable` whose iterators are not impacted by mutations to the underlying store.
- We will rename the API to `snapshot()` to actually indicate what its semantics is.
- We will return an immutable, point-in-time snapshot of the store. We will leverage the RocksDb's `db.snapshot()` instead of re-purposing `db.iterator()`. This will also ensure that the behavior is consistent across in-memory and rocks-db stores. The follow-up PR is in https://github.com/apache/samza/pull/510/files .
